head.title: The Nambu–Goto action as the one of the quantized space–time excitation.

article.h1: The Nambu–Goto action as the one of the quantized space–time excitation.

span.span:
Serge B. Afanas’ev
Sankt–Petersburg, Russia
e-mail: serg@ptslab.ioffe.rssi.ru

div.p: The concept of the quantized space–time of the formless finite fundamental elements is suggested. This space–time can be defined as a set of continual space–time coverings by simply connected non–overlapping regions of any form and arbitrary sizes with some probability measure. The functional integrating method and the space–time action problem are analyzed. A string in this space–time is considered as an excitation of a number of fundamental elements forming one–dimensional curve. It is possible to direct the way for the volume term of the space–time action to yield the Nambu–Goto action with this consideration.

Classical space–time is the continuum which is an arena for particles motion at their interaction. This concept of the space–time description remains in the quantum mechanics and the quantum field theory, where the space–time properties do not depend on particles structure and propagation, but particles are described by wave functions that have finite values in all space–time. Connection of the space–time structure and the matter is shown in the theory of gravitation. Classical gravitation theory space–time is the continuum also, but the quantum description of space–time properties at small distances is connected with the fundamental length (lfsubscript𝑙𝑓italic-l POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-f POSTSUBSCRIPT:endl_{f}) existence and discrete structure of the space–time.

The lattice space–time with the fixed lattice is most commonly investigated [1]. But the space–time with the fixed lattice consideration leads to several problems. The first and seemingly the most essential problem is the passage from the lattice space–time to the continuum in the limit lf→0→subscript𝑙𝑓0italic-l POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-f POSTSUBSCRIPT:end ARROW:to NUMBER:0l_{f}\to 0. The lattice space–time has the power of a countable set. Any subdivision of a lattice yields a set with the same power. Thus in the limit lf→0→subscript𝑙𝑓0italic-l POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-f POSTSUBSCRIPT:end ARROW:to NUMBER:0l_{f}\to 0 any lattice space–time with any subdivision remains a set with the power of a countable set. The second, the resulting equations in the lattice space and other spaces with determined fundamental element form depend on form of a fundamental element. The third, the equations in the lattice space are non-invariant under the continual symmetry operations.

Discrete geometry has been developed in the direction of the formless fundamental element in the last thirty years. The Regge calculus [3] and the space–time foam idea [4, 5] made the first steps on this way. In refs. [6] the stereohedra space is investigated. This space fundamental element has some set of forms. Random lattice field theory is analyzed in [2]. Quantum configuration space investigated in [7] is the method of quantized space–time description based on the not–fixed ”floating lattice”.

The alternative approach to the particle physics geometrical base is the superstring theory [8]. Strings are fundamental objects, their excited states describe all particles. But the strings are described as the geometrical objects that propagate in the background continual space–time. Therefore strings can be considered as the basic objects for fundamental particles description, but they cannot be considered as the fundamental units of the space–time.

In this work the concept of the space (space–time) that consists of the formless finite fundamental elements (FFFE) is suggested. On the one hand it makes the base for space–time quantization. Consideration of this concept leads to the idea of the space–time action with one of the terms proportional to the volume of FFFE. This method of space–time quantization is a consistently geometrical approach to the physics of fundamental particles and interactions. In this space–time the particles are excited states of the fundamental elements, and the interactions are connected with the transformations of the Riemannian space–time of FFFEs, that describes the space–time with particle–like excitations.

On the other hand the strings in this space–time picture can be considered as propagating excitations of any number of FFFEs, forming one- dimensional space–like curve (in the sense of FFFE space–time). The volume term of the space–time action of this excitation yields the Nambu–Goto action term. This picture of the quantized space–time and the strings as this space–time excitations enables to connect these approaches and assigns the meaning of fundamental space–time units for the strings.

The space of FFFEs can be defined as the set of coverings of the continual space by any number of non-overlapping simply connected regions of any form and arbitrary sizes. This set is provided with the probability measure, i.e. each covering contributes to the space with some probability. This measure enables the calculations based on this coverings set. Obviously, the probability measure like that the average values of sizes of FFFEs are equal to lfsubscript𝑙𝑓italic-l POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-f POSTSUBSCRIPT:endl_{f}, and the average number of FFFEs localized in the continual space region by the volume V𝑉italic-VV is N=[V⁢(lfn)-1]𝑁delimited-[]𝑉superscriptsuperscriptsubscript𝑙𝑓𝑛1italic-N RELOP:equals OPEN:[ italic-V OPEN:( italic-l POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-f POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start italic-n POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end CLOSE:) POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus NUMBER:1 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end CLOSE:]N=[V(l_{f}^{n})^{-1}]. But the configurations with the FFFEs sizes greatly different from lfsubscript𝑙𝑓italic-l POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-f POSTSUBSCRIPT:endl_{f} also have the finite probabilities. For example, the configurations where one fundamental element expands on all the space–time (or investigated manifold), or the configuration of continual space–time region itself, i.e. covering this region by points. This set of coverings have the power of continuum. Therefore limit passage from the space of FFFEs to the continual space can be carried out correctly.

The general construction for calculations on this coverings set is the continual (functional) integral. In agreement with the central idea of the continual integral theory the calculation of quantum quantities is the integrating over all possible configurations of the space–time of FFFEs (i.e. coverings of the space–time) with the corresponding probability measure taken into account.
Consider the general construction of a functional integral. In the plane space–time it is:

semantics.annotation: italic-Z RELOP:equals INTOP:integral caligraphic-D italic-V italic-e POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus italic-S OPEN:( italic-s POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-i POSTSUBSCRIPT:end CLOSE:) POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end PUNCT:,

div.p: where 𝒟⁢V𝒟𝑉caligraphic-D italic-V{\cal D}V is a measure on the set of coverings, S⁢(si)𝑆subscript𝑠𝑖italic-S OPEN:( italic-s POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-i POSTSUBSCRIPT:end CLOSE:)S(s_{i}) is the plane space–time vacuum action, sisubscript𝑠𝑖italic-s POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-i POSTSUBSCRIPT:ends_{i} is the set of the element parameters (sizes, areas, volume). Here integrating is over all coverings of the continual space by non-overlapping simply connected regions of any forms and any sizes. The average value of a function on a separate FFFE is defined by

semantics.annotation: RELOP:less-than italic-f OPEN:( OPEN:{ italic-a CLOSE:} CLOSE:) RELOP:greater-than-or-equals FRACOP:italic-divide ARG:start INTOP:integral caligraphic-D italic-V italic-e POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus italic-S OPEN:( italic-s POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-i POSTSUBSCRIPT:end CLOSE:) POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end italic-f POSTSUBSCRIPT:start OPEN:{ italic-a CLOSE:} POSTSUBSCRIPT:end OPEN:( italic-x POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start italic-i POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end CLOSE:) ARG:end ARG:start INTOP:integral caligraphic-D italic-V italic-e POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus italic-S OPEN:( italic-s POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-i POSTSUBSCRIPT:end CLOSE:) POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end ARG:end PUNCT:,

div.p: where f{a}⁢(xi)subscript𝑓𝑎superscript𝑥𝑖italic-f POSTSUBSCRIPT:start OPEN:{ italic-a CLOSE:} POSTSUBSCRIPT:end OPEN:( italic-x POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start italic-i POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end CLOSE:)f_{\{a\}}(x^{i}) are values of the function f𝑓italic-ff at regions of coverings set which forms the element with FFFE space–time coordinates {a}𝑎OPEN:{ italic-a CLOSE:}\{a\}, f⁢(xi)𝑓superscript𝑥𝑖italic-f OPEN:( italic-x POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start italic-i POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end CLOSE:)f(x^{i}) is a function defined in the continual space.

The functional integral construction requires the information about the action. The space–time vacuum action of the Minkowski space–time can depend on fundamental elements geometrical characteristics only: volume, m𝑚italic-mm–dimensional areas (m<n𝑚𝑛italic-m RELOP:less-than italic-nm<n), sizes. Suppose that one term of the four–dimensional space–time vacuum action is proportional to the volume of a fundamental element:

semantics.annotation: italic-S POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-v italic-a italic-c POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals italic-A ID:Planck-constant-over-2-pi POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus NUMBER:1 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end italic-G POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end italic-c POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:6 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end INTOP:integral POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-F italic-E POSTSUBSCRIPT:end italic-square-root ARG:start ADDOP:minus italic-eta ARG:end italic-d italic-V PUNCT:,

div.p: where A𝐴italic-AA is a numerical factor. Here d⁢V𝑑𝑉italic-d italic-VdV and -η𝜂italic-square-root ARG:start ADDOP:minus italic-eta ARG:end\sqrt{-\eta} are continual space values. Integrating in (3) is over one region from some covering of the continual space–time. This term is analogous to ”space–time foam” action proportional to the volume [4]. But this term of an action is unsufficient for description the equilibrium configuration of the space–time of FFFE. Total actions (3) of all configurations from the set of coverings are equal. The action minimum must correspond to the classical configuration, i.e. the continual space–time configuration in the considered case.

The complete expression for the space–time action, meeting this requirement, must contain other terms besides the volume term. The possible term is the one proportional to the total n-1𝑛1italic-n ADDOP:minus NUMBER:1n-1– dimensional area of FFFE. In this supposition the vacuum space–time action is

semantics.annotation: italic-S RELOP:equals italic-alpha SUMOP:sum POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-i POSTSUBSCRIPT:end italic-V POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-i POSTSUBSCRIPT:end ADDOP:plus italic-beta SUMOP:sum POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-i POSTSUBSCRIPT:end OPEN:( italic-S POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-n ADDOP:minus NUMBER:1 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end CLOSE:) POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-i POSTSUBSCRIPT:end PUNCT:,

div.p: where ∑isubscript𝑖SUMOP:sum POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-i POSTSUBSCRIPT:end\sum_{i} is summarizing over all FFFEs.

Let us direct the way, on which the Nambu–Goto term of the string action [8] might be obtained from the space–time action (3). The expression of the action of a space–time element for this analysis is required. This action is the average value of an action S𝑆italic-SS with the functional integrating (2) using. This action is denoted by SF⁢F⁢F⁢Esubscript𝑆𝐹𝐹𝐹𝐸italic-S POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-F italic-F italic-F italic-E POSTSUBSCRIPT:endS_{FFFE}:

semantics.annotation: italic-S POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-F italic-F italic-F italic-E POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals RELOP:less-than italic-S POSTSUBSCRIPT:start OPEN:{ italic-a CLOSE:} POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:greater-than RELOP:equals italic-A ID:Planck-constant-over-2-pi italic-L POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-p italic-l POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus NUMBER:4 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end INTOP:integral POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-F italic-F italic-F italic-E POSTSUBSCRIPT:end italic-square-root ARG:start ADDOP:minus italic-eta ARG:end italic-d italic-x POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:1 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end italic-d italic-x POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end italic-d italic-x POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:3 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end italic-d italic-x POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:4 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end

div.p: for the four–dimensional space–time.

A string in the space–time of FFFEs can be considered as an excitation of a number of FFFEs forming one–dimensional space–like structure (in the meaning of FFFE space–time). In the own reference frame the action of this excitation is represented in the form

semantics.annotation: italic-S RELOP:equals italic-A ID:Planck-constant-over-2-pi italic-L POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-p italic-l POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus NUMBER:4 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end INTOP:integral POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-F italic-F italic-F italic-E italic-s POSTSUBSCRIPT:end italic-square-root ARG:start ADDOP:minus italic-eta ARG:end italic-d italic-x POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:1 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end italic-d italic-x POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end italic-d italic-l italic-d italic-tau PUNCT:,

div.p: where τ𝜏italic-tau\tau is the own time, l𝑙italic-ll is the own space–like coordinate of an excitation, x1,x2superscript𝑥1superscript𝑥2italic-x POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:1 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end PUNCT:, italic-x POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:endx^{1},x^{2} are the transverse space–like coordinates. Here integrating is over a set of FFFEs, participated in the excitation propagation. Integrations over transverse coordinates yields the average values of FFFE sizes, i.e. lfsubscript𝑙𝑓italic-l POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-f POSTSUBSCRIPT:endl_{f}. In supposition lf≃Lp⁢lsimilar-to-or-equalssubscript𝑙𝑓subscript𝐿𝑝𝑙italic-l POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-f POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:similar-to-or-equals italic-L POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-p italic-l POSTSUBSCRIPT:endl_{f}\simeq L_{pl} we might obtain (γ𝛾italic-gamma\gamma is the two–dimensional metric tensor determinant):

semantics.annotation: italic-S RELOP:equals italic-A ID:Planck-constant-over-2-pi italic-L POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-p italic-l POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end INTOP:integral italic-d italic-l italic-d italic-tau italic-square-root ARG:start ADDOP:minus italic-gamma ARG:end PUNCT:,

div.p: i.e. the Nambu–Goto action for a string. This result is not completely correct due to the transformation problem of the four–dimensional metric tensor determinant η𝜂italic-eta\eta in (6) to the two–dimensional one γ𝛾italic-gamma\gamma in (7) and absence of the correct definition of one–dimensional integrating. In this concept the p𝑝italic-pp–branes are considered as the p𝑝italic-pp–dimensional space–like excitations of FFFEs, and the volume term (6) of the FFFE space–time excitation yields the bosonic term of p𝑝italic-pp–branes action analogically.

Consideration of the strings as the excitations of the quantized space–time is the step to the understanding of the superstrings properties at the Plank distances. With this strings and p𝑝italic-pp–branes consideration all these objects are identical at the Plank distances because the excitation of one element does not have dimension in the sense of FFFE space–time.

The author thanks M.S. Orlov, A.V. Klochkov, E.V. Klochkova, A.V. Sokolov, G.S. Sokolova, A.B. Vankov for their friendly support during the work time, A.A. Amerikantsev, M.E. Golod, A.N. Lobanov for their technical assistance and M.A. Tyntarev for useful discussions.
